articles.headline: How Kamala Harris Took Command of the Democratic Party in 48 Hours
articles.snippet: She worked the phones. Her team worked the delegates. When it was over, she had quickly locked down the nomination in a “well-orchestrated cascade,” as one party leader put it.
articles.abstract: She worked the phones. Her team worked the delegates. When it was over, she had quickly locked down the nomination in a “well-orchestrated cascade,” as one party leader put it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow the latest news about the 2024 election, and the Trump and Harris campaigns.

articles.headline: Netanyahu Delivers a Forceful Defense of Israel to Applause in Congress
articles.snippet: The speech by Israel’s leader was charged with symbolism, as the war in Gaza has divided lawmakers. He portrayed the conflict as a proxy fight with Iran that must be won at all costs and condemned protesters.
articles.abstract: The speech by Israel’s leader was charged with symbolism, as the war in Gaza has divided lawmakers. He portrayed the conflict as a proxy fight with Iran that must be won at all costs and condemned protesters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Wednesday turned an address to Congress into a forceful defense of Israel’s military campaign in Gaza. He cast it as a battle for survival of the Jewish state while making almost no mention of the tens of thousands of Palestinian civilians killed in its drive to destroy Hamas.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: N.B.A. Announces Lucrative Rights Deals With Disney, Comcast and Amazon
articles.snippet: The league rejected a bid by Warner Bros. Discovery to match Amazon’s offer.
articles.abstract: The league rejected a bid by Warner Bros. Discovery to match Amazon’s offer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The National Basketball Association announced new rights agreements with Disney, Comcast and Amazon on Wednesday after rejecting a rival bid by Warner Bros. Discovery that would have kept games on its TNT network, which has broadcast the N.B.A. since the 1980s.
articles.byline: By Tania Ganguli, Kevin Draper and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: The Secret Battle for the Future of the Murdoch Empire
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch, the patriarch, has moved to change the family’s irrevocable trust to preserve his media businesses as a conservative force. Several of his children are fighting back.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch, the patriarch, has moved to change the family’s irrevocable trust to preserve his media businesses as a conservative force. Several of his children are fighting back.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch is locked in a secret legal battle against three of his children over the future of the family’s media empire, as he moves to preserve it as a conservative political force after his death, according to a sealed court document obtained by The New York Times.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jonathan Mahler

articles.headline: Biden Says It Is Time to Step Aside for a Fresh, Younger Voice
articles.snippet: In an Oval Office address, President Biden praised Vice President Kamala Harris and said “it’s been the privilege of my life to serve this nation for over 50 years.”
articles.abstract: In an Oval Office address, President Biden praised Vice President Kamala Harris and said “it’s been the privilege of my life to serve this nation for over 50 years.”
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden told the American public in an Oval Office address on Wednesday that he had abandoned his re-election campaign because there is “a time and a place for new voices, fresh voices — yes, younger voices.”

articles.headline: Before Paris, London Showed How the Olympics Could Be Sustainable
articles.snippet: Paris aims to be the most sustainable Olympic Games in history, but it was London over a decade ago that proved host cities didn’t have to end up with empty stadiums in disrepair after the Games were over.
articles.abstract: Paris aims to be the most sustainable Olympic Games in history, but it was London over a decade ago that proved host cities didn’t have to end up with empty stadiums in disrepair after the Games were over.
articles.lead_paragraph: This week, the world will tune in to watch what is being billed as the most sustainable Olympic Games in history, a goal the organizers of the Paris Games aim to reach in part by refurbishing buildings instead of constructing new ones.

articles.headline: The Illicit Flow of Technology to Russia Goes Through This Hong Kong Address
articles.snippet: Defying sanctions, Russia has obtained nearly $4 billion in restricted chips since the war began in Ukraine. Many were shipped through a cluster of shell companies in Hong Kong.
articles.abstract: Defying sanctions, Russia has obtained nearly $4 billion in restricted chips since the war began in Ukraine. Many were shipped through a cluster of shell companies in Hong Kong.
articles.lead_paragraph: From a nondescript seventh-floor office at 135 Bonham Strand near Hong Kong’s financial district, at least four companies are operating with a shadowy mission: facilitating the illicit trade of Western technology to Russia.
articles.byline: By Aaron Krolik and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Elon Musk Wants People on X to Police Election Posts. It’s Not Working Well.
articles.snippet: The social media company will use its Community Notes program to moderate lies about the election, but cracks are already appearing.
articles.abstract: The social media company will use its Community Notes program to moderate lies about the election, but cracks are already appearing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Less than an hour after President Biden endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris as the Democratic candidate for president on Sunday, users on X falsely claimed she was “ineligible” to run for office because her parents were not born in the United States.

articles.headline: Tech Stocks Are Out. Small Stocks Are In. Can That Last?
articles.snippet: Shifting views on the economy have led to a “rotation” in the stock market. Small stocks and companies geared toward the economic cycle are rising. Big Tech is lagging.
articles.abstract: Shifting views on the economy have led to a “rotation” in the stock market. Small stocks and companies geared toward the economic cycle are rising. Big Tech is lagging.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something appears to have shifted in the stock market. For the moment, at least.

articles.headline: U.S. Economic Growth Accelerates, Outpacing Forecasts
articles.snippet: Gross domestic product rose at a 2.8 percent annual rate in the second quarter, new evidence of the economy’s resilience despite high interest rates.
articles.abstract: Gross domestic product rose at a 2.8 percent annual rate in the second quarter, new evidence of the economy’s resilience despite high interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economic growth picked up more than expected in the spring, as cooling inflation and a strong labor market allowed consumers to keep spending even as high interest rates weighed on their finances.

articles.headline: 2025 Could Be a Great Time to Be President, Economically Speaking
articles.snippet: Trends already underway make for a sunny outlook over the next few years. The question is who will get to take credit.
articles.abstract: Trends already underway make for a sunny outlook over the next few years. The question is who will get to take credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: The next couple of years are shaping up to be solid for the U.S. economy. Inflation is returning to normal. As that happens, the Federal Reserve is preparing to cut interest rates. A huge burst of infrastructure spending under the Biden administration has taken time to ramp up, but projects both small and large are likely to break ground in earnest in 2025 and 2026.

articles.headline: Newsom Orders California Officials to Remove Homeless Encampments
articles.snippet: The directive from Gov. Gavin Newsom is the nation’s most sweeping response to a Supreme Court decision last month that gave local leaders greater authority to remove homeless campers.
articles.abstract: The directive from Gov. Gavin Newsom is the nation’s most sweeping response to a Supreme Court decision last month that gave local leaders greater authority to remove homeless campers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom ordered California state officials on Thursday to begin dismantling thousands of homeless encampments, the nation’s most sweeping response to a recent Supreme Court ruling that gave governments greater authority to remove homeless people from their streets.
